Domain: Care of Acute and Chronic Conditions
Measure Name: Asthma Medication Ratio: Ages 5 to 18
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage with Persistent Asthma who had a Ratio of Controller Medications to Total Asthma Medications of 0.50 or Greater: Ages 5 to 11
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Medicaid rates include FFS and PCCM populations. State reported that rates exclude the following populations: "Since Medicare claims are unavailable, Alabama Medicaid Agency recipients who are dually enrolled in Medicaid and Medicare are excluded from the eligible population." Rates were audited or validated. This measure is included in our Alabama Coordinated Healthcare Networks (ACHN) quality incentive payment structure, and has received particular attention by the ACHN Networks to whom these financial incentive payments are made. This substantial rate increase is largely due to the increased effort on the part of the ACHN Network Entities.

Measure Name: Contraceptive Care: Postpartum Women Ages 15 to 20
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage of Postpartum Women Provided a Most Effective or Moderately Effective Method of Contraception Within 3 Days of Delivery: Ages 15 to 20
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Medicaid rates include FFS and PCCM populations. State reported that rates exclude the following populations: "Since Medicare claims are unavailable, Alabama Medicaid Agency recipients who are dually enrolled in Medicaid and Medicare are excluded from the eligible population." Alabama Medicaid analysis has shown using 'CMS provided values sets only' did not accurately provide the number deliveries that happened in the state. Therefore, the agency utilizes hospital claims data, case management data and maternity claims data in addition to the value sets provided for the measure specifications. Further, we use Vital Statistics Birth Certificate data as a validation tool and have found that this methodology is highly effective.

This measure is included in our Alabama Coordinated Healthcare Networks (ACHN) quality incentive payment structure, and has received particular attention by the ACHN Networks to whom these financial incentive payments are made. This substantial rate increase from previous years is largely due to the increased effort on the part of the ACHN Network Entities.

Domain: Primary Care Access and Preventive Care
Measure Name: Chlamydia Screening in Women Ages 16 to 20
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage of Sexually Active Women Screened for Chlamydia: Ages 16 to 20
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Medicaid rate includes FFS and PCCM populations. State reported that the rate excludes the following populations: "Since Medicare claims are unavailable, Alabama Medicaid Agency recipients who are dually enrolled in Medicaid and Medicare are excluded from the eligible population." Alabama Medicaid Policy stipulates that when chlamydia and gonorrhea are tested on the same date visit, the CPT Code 87801 is to be used. This code is not in the HEDIS Value Set, and is not included for reporting. If this code were to be included, Alabama Rates would more than double.

Domain: Care of Acute and Chronic Conditions
Measure Name: Ambulatory Care: Emergency Department (ED) Visits: Ages 0 to 19
Measure Type: Lower rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Emergency Department Visits per 1,000 Beneficiary Months: Ages 0 to 19
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rate includes FFS population. Because the denominator is based on eligibility months rather than eligible recipients, clear division was possible between Medicaid and CHIP segments. Age for each recipient was calculated as the age as of the 15th of each month. Based on a child's age as of the 15th of each month, a decision was made to which age group this the respective month belonged. The program determination was made based on the eligibility file, not the claims data. Numerator: The age grouping was based on the age of the recipients on the date on service. All exclusion value sets were used for this measure. There may be some underreporting due to timely filing lag.

AK Medicaid providers use 96110 to bill for different types of developmental screening that might include the ASQ-SE and the M-CHAT, because AK Medicaid does not yet have policy to use a modifier to identify when one of the eight NQF endorsed standardized developmental screening tools has been used. For this reason, the use of modifiers was taken into account in compiling this measure. Claims filed with procedure code modifiers other than "33" were not included.

Rate Definition: Percentage Receiving Meningococcal Conjugate and Tdap Vaccines (Combination 1) by Their 13th Birthday
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rates include FFS, PCCM and managed care populations (3 MCOs). State reported that rates exclude the following populations: "Medicare/Medicaid dual eligible beneficiaries identified in the measurement year. For continuous enrollment exclusions, calculation excluded eligibility segments for Medicare Assistance and non-Medicaid aid category codes." The state described the "other" data sources used to calculate the measure as the following: "claims and immunization registry data were used together to obtain immunization records for the entire eligible population." Rates were audited or validated.

Domain: Primary Care Access and Preventive Care
Measure Name: Well-Child Visits in the First 30 Months of Life
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure

For continuous enrollment exclusions, calculation excluded eligibility segments for Medicare Assistance and non-Medicaid aid category codes." Rates were audited or validated. State reported the following deviations: "Added newborn care CPT codes 99460 and 99463." To identify PCPs, state used applicable Medicaid provider types. Calculation used eligibility data and state did not verify if beneficiaries had medical benefits.

Measure Name: Prenatal and Postpartum Care: Timeliness of Prenatal Care
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage of Women Delivering a Live Birth with a Prenatal Care Visit in the First Trimester, on or before the enrollment start date, or within 42 Days of Enrollment in Medicaid or CHIP
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rate includes FFS and managed care populations (25 MCOs). The state described the "other" data sources used to calculate the measure as the following: "Managed care plan for Kaiser North and South reported administratively." Rate was derived using both administrative and hybrid method data. Denominator is the measure-eligible population. Rate is provisional. Rate was audited or validated. FFY 2021 rate is lower than the state's FFY 2020 rate due to denominator increase associated with adherence to the continuous coverage requirements under the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA) during the federally designated Public Health Emergency (PHE) and disenrollment being suspended. The rate decrease could also be due to COVID-19's impact on services.

The COVID-19 pandemic significantly impacted the normal process of implementing, measuring, and evaluating quality and health outcomes for the HUSKY Health program. Decreases in access and service delivery issues impacted emergency department (ED), inpatient and well-care utilization. The impact of the pandemic has been wide-ranging for HUSKY Health. The social distancing measures and changes in healthcare priorities resulted in decreases in in-person visits. Well care, ED, and inpatient utilization decreased as members avoided healthcare facilities and hospitals focused on helping those with COVID-19 or life-threatening situations. In addition, for much of 2020, elective procedures were put on hold. Further, virtual visits have impacted CT Medicaid and CHIP interventions that require travel or in-person interaction with members and providers.

Fee-For-Service, MediKids, and Children's Medical Services Health Plan (CMSHP) used the hybrid methodology. Florida Healthy Kids is not included because the age group is not applicable for this measure. Thirteen Medicaid Managed Care plans used the hybrid methodology and 2 plans reported using the administrative methodology. The measure-eligible population is 107,515. Rates were audited or validated. Medicaid managed care plans were only required to collect and submit rates for Combination 2 and Combination 3.

Rate Definition: Percentage who had at Least Two Flu Vaccinations by their Second Birthday
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rates include managed care population (5 MCOs). The state described the "other" data sources used to calculate the measure as the following: "Managed care claim rates were calculated on a per-plan basis using the hybrid method with data coming from an appropriate source as determined by NCQA-certified Managed Care Plans." Denominator is the sample size; measure-eligible population is 52,205. Rates were audited or validated.

Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure

Oklahoma bills using global codes (bundled service codes) for prenatal and postpartum care. The measure specifications do not allow for global codes. If global codes are permitted, Oklahoma's rate is: Numerator: 7,676; Denominator: 21,716; Rate: 35.3%.

Measure Name: Follow-Up After Hospitalization for Mental Illness: Ages 6 to 17
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage of Hospitalizations for Mental Illness or Intentional Self-Harm with a Follow-Up Visit Within 7 Days after Discharge: Ages 6 to 17
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rates include FFS population. State reported that rates exclude the following populations: "Any recipient with dates of service during the measure year at a Psychiatric Residential Treatment Facility (PRTF) was excluded from both the denominator and numerator because they would not have had separate codes billed for the follow-up." State reported the following deviations: "Since community mental health center (CMHC) visits count towards the numerator, we added a code, H2021, to the value sets. South Dakota Medicaid uses H2021 as a billable service for CMHCs funded through the Department of Social Services."

Measure Name: Follow-Up After Hospitalization for Mental Illness: Ages 6 to 17
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage of Hospitalizations for Mental Illness or Intentional Self-Harm with a Follow-Up Visit Within 7 Days after Discharge: Ages 6 to 17
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Medicaid rates include FFS and managed care populations (16 MCOs). The state described the "other" data sources used to calculate the measure as the following: "Two data sources were used to calculate the quality of care indicators: member level enrollment information and member level health care claims/encounter data. The enrollment files contained information about the member's age, gender, the MCO, and program in which the member is enrolled per month. Member-level claims/encounter data contained CPT, ICD10-CM, and Place of Service codes, and other information necessary to calculate the quality of care indicators." Rates were audited or validated.

Rate Definition: Percentage who had a New Prescription for an Antipsychotic Medication and had Documentation of Psychosocial Care as First-Line Treatment: Ages 1 to 17
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: CHIP rate includes managed care population (15 MCOs). The state described the "other" data sources used to calculate the measure as the following: "Two data sources were used to calculate the quality of care indicators: member level enrollment information and member level health care claims/encounter data. The enrollment files contained information about the member's age, gender, the MCO, and program in which the member is enrolled per month. Member-level claims/encounter data contained CPT, ICD10-CM, and Place of Service codes, and other information necessary to calculate the quality of care indicators." Rate was audited or validated.

Domain: Primary Care Access and Preventive Care
Measure Name: Immunizations for Adolescents: Age 13
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage Completing the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Vaccine Series by Their 13th Birthday
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Medicaid rates include FFS and managed care populations (16 MCOs). The state described the "other" data sources used to calculate the measure as the following: "Two data sources were used to calculate the quality of care indicators: member level enrollment information and member level health care claims/encounter data. Member-level claims/encounter data contained CPT, ICD10-CM, and Place of Service codes, and other information necessary to calculate the quality of care indicators." Results were based on both administrative and hybrid data sources. Administrative data sources were used for State of Texas Access Reform (STAR) Health and FFS, while hybrid data sources were used for CHIP, STAR, and STAR Kids. Denominator is the measure-eligible population. Rates were audited or validated.

Measure Name: Follow-Up Care for Children Prescribed Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) Medication: Ages 6 to 12
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure

Measure Name: Contraceptive Care: All Women Ages 15 to 20
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage of Women at Risk for Unintended Pregnancy Provided a Most Effective or Moderately Effective Method of Contraception: Ages 15 to 20
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rates include FFS, PCCM and managed care populations (5 MCOs). State reported that rates exclude the following populations: "Dual Medicaid/Medicare eligibles and those with full third-party liability." State reported the following deviations: "Specifications instruct to include all paid, suspended, pending, and denied claims. We report using a data source of paid claims. The only denied claims included are denied lines from otherwise accepted encounters. Used GPI instead of NDC to identify the applicable NDCs for specific methods. Required FP modifier for 11981 and 11983 to verify contraceptive use (as required by WA). Did not use S4993 alone as indication of oral contraception, as WA also uses S4993 to indicate emergency contraception."

Measure Name: Contraceptive Care: Postpartum Women Ages 15 to 20
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage of Postpartum Women Provided a Most Effective or Moderately Effective Method of Contraception Within 3 Days of Delivery: Ages 15 to 20
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rates include FFS, PCCM and managed care populations (5 MCOs). State reported that rates exclude the following populations: "Dual Medicaid/Medicare eligibles and those with full third-party liability." State reported the following deviations: "Used GPI to identify the applicable NDCs for specific methods. Did not use S4993 alone as indication of oral contraception, as WA also uses S4993 to indicate emergency contraception. Required FP modifier for 11981 and 11983 to verify contraceptive use (as required by WA). Reported using paid claims. The only denied claims included are denied lines from otherwise accepted encounters. Used procedure code dates for delivery dates instead of the ICD-10 codes as they were more accurate when compared with birth certificate dates. Did not use the global OB code 59400 to identify births if it was paired with a diagnosis code for encounter for supervision of a pregnancy of less than 19 weeks gestation as this misidentified prenatal care as births."

State-Specific Comments: CMS calculated rate using CDC WONDER data.

Measure Name: Low-Risk Cesarean Delivery
Measure Type: Lower rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage of Nulliparous, Term, Singleton, in a Cephalic Presentation Births Delivered by Cesarean
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Wide-ranging Online Data for Epidemiologic Research (CDC WONDER) data as of February 2, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: CMS calculated rate using CDC WONDER data.

Measure Name: Prenatal and Postpartum Care: Timeliness of Prenatal Care
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage of Women Delivering a Live Birth with a Prenatal Care Visit in the First Trimester, on or before the enrollment start date, or within 42 Days of Enrollment in Medicaid or CHIP
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rate includes FFS, PCCM, and managed care populations (5 MCOs). State reported that the rate excludes the following populations: "Medicaid/Medicare eligibles and those with full third-party liability." Administrative data sources are claims/encounters and vital records. State reported the following deviations: "Evaluated first trimester based on gestational age at birth in addition to the specified 176-280 days before delivery; since our administrative records always have an enrollment start date of the first of the month, for this analysis estimation of 42 days from enrollment start has been calculated from the 15th of the month to spread out bias for administrative vs actual start of enrollment; excludes records with missing birth certificate information about when prenatal care began that were not otherwise in the numerator (6.8 % of otherwise eligible women); measurement period is calendar year; rates include paid claims and denied lines from otherwise accepted encounters."

Domain: Primary Care Access and Preventive Care
Measure Name: Weight Assessment and Counseling for Nutrition and Physical Activity for Children/Adolescents: Ages 3 to 17
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Body Mass Index Percentile Documentation: Ages 3 to 17
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rates include managed care population (5 MCOs). State reported that rates exclude the following populations: "FFS, PCCM, and managed care clients who meet the continuous eligibility requirement for Medicaid/CHIP but who were not enrolled in a single plan during the continuous eligibility enrollment, or who switched between FFS and Managed Care, are not included. HEDIS plan data were used for consistency, for avoidance of redundant work, because these rates are audited and are used as a basis for discussions with plans, and because, since a majority of our clients are now enrolled in managed care, it is largely representative of our caseload." The state noted: "The measure eligible populations for each reporting unit are used to weight the rates." Denominator is the sample size; measure-eligible population is 366,773. Rates were audited or validated.

Domain: Primary Care Access and Preventive Care
Measure Name: Well-Child Visits in the First 30 Months of Life
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure

Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rates include FFS, PCCM and managed care populations (5 MCOs). State reported that rates exclude the following populations: "Dual Medicaid/Medicare eligibles and those with full third-party liability." The state described the "other" data sources used to calculate the measure as the following: "Birth Certificates (linking mom and baby to get additional visits on Mom's record)." The state reported the following deviations: "Rates include paid claims and denied lines from otherwise accepted encounters; specifications state that the visit must occur with a PCP but the state has assumed that the targeted medical codes will be associated with appropriate personnel and is not applying this screen, due to the likelihood of underrepresenting qualifying visits. For visits during the first two months, mothers have been identified where possible, and claims for visits per the specified CPTs on mother's Medicaid ID have been added to the infant claims."

Measure Name: Follow-Up After Hospitalization for Mental Illness: Ages 6 to 17
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage of Hospitalizations for Mental Illness or Intentional Self-Harm with a Follow-Up Visit Within 7 Days after Discharge: Ages 6 to 17
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: CHIP rates include FFS and managed care populations (3 MCOs). The state described the "other" data sources used to calculate the measure as the following: "State's Data Warehouse, separate from the MMIS." The State's Data Warehouse vendor is certified by HEDIS for this measure. The logic includes the following allowable adjustments: 1) age is as of Admission but the age groups were defined by end of measurement period; 2) continuous enrollment was adjusted; 3) most health plans do not carve out chemical dependency, so this requirement was dropped; 4) the rates evaluate only the first two events to meet the allowable adjustment criteria; 5) no restrictions on data type for the files that are submitted for processing.

Measure Name: Follow-Up Care for Children Prescribed Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) Medication: Ages 6 to 12
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage Newly Prescribed ADHD Medication with 1 Follow-Up Visit During the 30-Day Initiation Phase: Ages 6 to 12
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: CHIP rates include FFS and managed care populations (3 MCOs). The state described the "other" data sources used to calculate the measure as the following: "State's Data Warehouse, separate from the MMIS." We are aware that the rate for FFY 2021 is about 10 percentage points higher than for FFY 2020. We believe that several driving factors for this are: 1. Small denominator size; 2. Opening of telehealth codes during the COVID-19 public health emergency; and 3. Alignment of the resources for CHIP reporting to that of the Medicaid population. The State's Data Warehouse vendor is certified by HEDIS for this measure. The logic includes the following allowable adjustments: 1) The Age range was defined with a relative date of 10 months from start of the measurement year to end age range of 10 months from the end of measurement year. 2) No restrictions on data type for the files that are submitted for processing.

Domain: Care of Acute and Chronic Conditions
Measure Name: Ambulatory Care: Emergency Department (ED) Visits: Ages 0 to 19
Measure Type: Lower rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Emergency Department Visits per 1,000 Beneficiary Months: Ages 0 to 19
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: CHIP rate includes FFS and managed care populations (3 MCOs). The state described the "other" data sources used to calculate the measure as the following: "State's Data Warehouse, separate from the MMIS." We are aware that the FFY 2021 rate is higher than the FFY 2020 rate. It is unknown what caused the increase but suspect that closures, social distancing measures, stay at home orders, etc. during the COVID-19 public health emergency resulting in decreased preventive services and therefore, increased ED usage.

Measure Name: Chlamydia Screening in Women Ages 21 to 24
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage of Sexually Active Women Screened for Chlamydia: Ages 21 to 24
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.

State reported that the rate excludes the following populations: "Since Medicare claims are unavailable, Alabama Medicaid Agency recipients who are dually enrolled in Medicaid and Medicare are excluded from the eligible population." Alabama Medicaid Policy stipulates that when chlamydia and conorrhea are tested on the same date visit, the CPT Code 87801 is to be used. This code is not in the HEDIS Value Set and is not included for reporting. If this code were to be included, Alabama rates would more than double.

Domain: Primary Care Access and Preventive Care
Measure Name: Cervical Cancer Screening: Ages 21 to 64
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage of Women Screened for Cervical Cancer: Ages 21 to 64
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rate includes FFS and managed care populations (25 MCOs). The state described the "other" data sources used to calculate the measure as the following: "Managed care plans including Kaiser North and South, Aetna Better Health of California, CalOptima, and Health Net Community Solutions (Los Angeles County) reported administratively." Rate was derived using both administrative and hybrid method data. Denominator is the measure-eligible population. Rate is provisional. Rate was audited or validated. Ages 21 to 64 rate is substantially lower than the state's FFY 2020 rate (60.0), partly due to denominator increase associated with adherence to the continuous coverage requirements under the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA) during the federally designated Public Health Emergency (PHE) and disenrollment being suspended. Rate decrease could also be due to the impact of COVID-19 on services.

Measure Name: Medical Assistance With Smoking and Tobacco Use Cessation: Age 18 and older
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure

Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rates include managed care population (2 MCOs). The state described the "other" population included in the measure as the following: "Members eligible for the survey were those 18 years and older (as of December 31 of the measurement year) who were continuously enrolled in the plan for at least five of the last six months of the measurement year." State reported the following deviations: "Ages 18+ were included due to aggregation of age ranges captured. MCOs used different age ranges so all adults were combined."

Domain: Care of Acute and Chronic Conditions
Measure Name: Comprehensive Diabetes Care: Hemoglobin A1c Poor Control (>9.0%): Ages 18 to 75
Measure Type: Lower rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage with Diabetes (Type 1 or Type 2) who had Hemoglobin A1c in Poor Control (>9.0%): Ages 18 to 64
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rate includes managed care population (9 MCOs). State reported that the rate excludes the following populations: "The Medicare and Medicaid dually-eligible population are carved out of managed care." The state implemented optional exclusions for members without a diagnosis, members with gestational diabetes, and members with steroid-induced diabetes. Denominator is the sample size; measure-eligible population is 49,853. Rate was audited or validated. State reported the following deviation: "Rate includes members 18-75." Jai Medical Services reported administratively.

Rate Definition: Percentage Diagnosed with Major Depression who were Treated with and Remained on Antidepressant Medication for 12 Weeks: Ages 18 to 64
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rates include FFS and managed care populations (8 MCOs). Rates were audited or validated. Rates include paid and denied claims. Substantial increase in denominator could be due to technical specification change. For example, Telehealth visits type are now counted. Also, technical specifications for 2020 (FFY 2021) ended up excluding fewer individuals as it expanded how we define the major depression diagnosis that is required for this measure, which meant the eligible population increased substantially in 2020.

Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure

Medicaid enrollment continues to increase due to the population's Medicaid eligibility being protected under the ongoing public health emergency (PHE).

Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rates include managed care population (3 MCOs). FFS enrollees and Medicare and Medicaid dually-eligible population are excluded. The state described the "other" data sources used to calculate the measure as the following: "The managed care organizations' data are from their claims system." Rates were audited or validated. Submitted values are based on HEDIS data for reporting year 2021, yet the age groups were split up according to the CMS specified age group for that measure where it was applicable. This reporting year a third MCO is added, therefore, denominators and Measure Eligible Population also represent the totals of the three MCOs. Medicaid enrollment continues to increase due to the population's Medicaid eligibility being protected under the ongoing public health emergency (PHE).

Measure Name: Concurrent Use of Opioids and Benzodiazepines: Age 18 and older
Measure Type: Lower rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage with Concurrent Use of Prescription Opioids and Benzodiazepines: Ages 18 to 64
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rate includes managed care population (8 MCOs). The state described the "other" data sources used to calculate the measure as the following: "Data submitted by managed care plans and compiled by the EQRO." Rate was audited or validated. There are no Medicare or dual-eligibles included in the Pennsylvania HealthChoices managed care program. State reported that there were mixed results among plans, with both significant increases and significant decreases. Plans with increases noted there are more mental health issues during the pandemic which can increase benzodiazepine usage potentially leading to opioid use. For decreases, it was noted that due to the pandemic, members avoided non-emergent services, which may have contributed to an observed decline in the denominator.

Measure Name: Adherence to Antipsychotic Medications for Individuals with Schizophrenia: Age 18 and older
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage with Schizophrenia or Schizoaffective Disorder who were Dispensed and Remained on Antipsychotic Medication for at Least 80 Percent of their Treatment Period: Age 18 and older
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rate includes FFS and managed care populations (17 MCOs). The state described the "other" data sources used to calculate the measure as the following: "Two data sources were used to calculate the quality of care indicators: member level enrollment information and member level health care claims/encounter data. The enrollment files contained information about the member's age, gender, the MCO, and program in which the member is enrolled per month. Member-level claims/encounter data contained CPT, ICD10-CM, and Place of Service codes, and other information necessary to calculate the quality of care indicators." Rate was audited or validated.

Measure Name: Initiation and Engagement of Alcohol and Other Drug Abuse or Dependence Treatment: Age 18 and Older
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage with a New Episode of Alcohol Abuse or Dependence who Initiated Alcohol or Other Drug Treatment within 14 Days of the Diagnosis: Ages 18 to 64
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rates include "other" delivery system (Vermont Medicaid is operated under managed care as a public non-risk prepaid inpatient health plan). Rates were audited or validated. State reported the following deviations: "Our modified measure includes residential SUD treatment as initiation or engagement events where appropriate following the HEDIS specifications for sub-acute IP. When the residential SUD treatment event is the index, both index and initiation dates are set as the last day of residential SUD treatment. Our modified measure examines the start and end date of service to determine if initiation and/or treatment engagement occurs. The first month of Hub services are counted as initiation. If there is no gap in Hub services, the next month is counted as engagement." DVHA's EQRO advised to report Medicaid Primary for administrative measures and IET visits include pharmacy. DVHA does not capture pharmacy claims for duals in a reliable manner, therefore state did not include them.

State-Specific Comments: Rates include FFS, PCCM and managed care populations (5 MCOs). State reported that rates exclude the following populations: "Dual Medicaid/Medicare eligibles and those with full third-party liability." State reported the following deviations: "Used GPI instead of NDC to identify the applicable NDCs for specific methods. Did not use S4993 alone as indication of oral contraception, as WA also uses S4993 to indicate emergency contraception. Required FP modifier for 11981 and 11983 to verify contraceptive use (as required by WA). Specifications instruct to include all paid, suspended, pending, and denied claims. We report using a data source of paid claims. The only denied claims included are denied lines from otherwise accepted encounters."Rates include FFS, PCCM and managed care populations (5 MCOs). We report using a data source of paid claims. The only denied claims included are denied lines from otherwise accepted encounters."

Measure Name: Contraceptive Care: Postpartum Women Ages 21 to 44
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage of Postpartum Women Provided a Most Effective or Moderately Effective Method of Contraception Within 3 Days of Delivery: Ages 21 to 44
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rates include FFS, PCCM and managed care populations (5 MCOs). State reported that rates exclude the following populations: "Dual Medicaid/Medicare eligibles and those with full third-party liability." State reported the following deviations: "Used GPI to identify the applicable NDCs for specific methods. Did not use S4993 alone as indication of oral contraception, as WA also uses S4993 to indicate emergency contraception. Required FP modifier for 11981 and 11983 to verify contraceptive use (as required by WA). Reported using paid claims. The only denied claims included are denied lines from otherwise accepted encounters. We used procedure code dates for delivery dates instead of the ICD-10 codes as they were more accurate when compared with birth certificate dates. We did not use the global OB code 59400 to identify births if it was paired with a diagnosis code for encounter for supervision of a pregnancy of less than 19 weeks gestation as this misidentified prenatal care as births."

The State's Data Warehouse vendor is certified by HEDIS for this measure. The logic includes the following allowable adjustments: Age can be adjusted as long as age range was not changed or expanded. Organizations are not required to limit criteria for supplemental data or denied data. All data has been used when evaluating eligible population, numerator, and exclusion criteria. No restrictions on data type for the files that are submitted for processing.

The Age range was defined with a relative date of 8 months from the end of the prior measurement year to 8 months prior to the end of the current measurement year. Organizations are not required to limit criteria for supplemental data or denied data. All data has been used when evaluating eligible population, numerator, and exclusion criteria. No restrictions on data type for the files that are submitted for processing.

Measure Name: Initiation and Engagement of Alcohol and Other Drug Abuse or Dependence Treatment: Age 18 and Older
Measure Type: Higher rates are better for this measure
Rate Definition: Percentage with a New Episode of Alcohol Abuse or Dependence who Initiated Alcohol or Other Drug Treatment within 14 Days of the Diagnosis: Ages 18 to 64
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rates include FFS and managed care populations (3 MCOs). The state described the "other" data sources used to calculate the measure as the following: "State's Data Warehouse, separate from the MMIS." West Virginia Medicaid has an 1115 waiver targeting substance use disorder that began in calendar year 2018. Medication assisted treatment (MAT) for WV Medicaid members require therapeutic intervention to begin & continue MAT. The state's Data Warehouse vendor was NCQA certified for this measure with the following allowable adjustments: age was defined based on the end of measurement year (MY); numerator period is set to a relative time from the beginning of the MY to 47 days prior to the end of the MY; no restrictions on data type for the files that are submitted for processing; most claims data did not identify MHSA coverage & included it under medical coverage so eligibility was defined using medical coverage.

Rate Definition: Percentage of Women who had a Mammogram to Screen for Breast Cancer: Ages 50 to 64
Source: Mathematica analysis of the Quality Measure Reporting (QMR) system reports for the FFY 2021 reporting cycle as of June 1, 2023.
State-Specific Comments: Rate includes FFS and managed care populations (3 MCOs). The state described the "other" data sources used to calculate the measure as the following: "State's Data Warehouse, separate from the MMIS." The State's Data Warehouse vendor is certified by HEDIS for this measure. The logic includes the following allowable adjustments: Age can be adjusted as long as age range was not changed or expanded. Age was defined based on the end of measurement year. Organizations are not required to limit criteria for supplemental data or denied data. All data has been used when evaluating eligible population, numerator, and exclusion criteria. No restrictions on data type for the files that are submitted for processing.
